Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of deaths in Germany after receiving the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine by stating "10 Dead in Germany after Receiving Pfizer COVID-19 Vaccine" without providing the necessary context that these deaths were not linked to the vaccinations.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only provides a screenshot of a headline without any additional evidence or sources to back up the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the deaths in Germany were directly caused by the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine without considering alternative explanations or underlying health conditions.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict states that the deaths in Germany were not linked to the vaccinations and were due to complications of pre-existing diseases, providing an alternative explanation to the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the deaths in Germany were not linked to the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine, as confirmed by medical experts and the Paul Ehrlich Institute.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting a misleading context by omitting crucial information from the original article, which accurately states that the deaths were not caused by the vaccines.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
